name: Introduction to Price Action
description:
Price action trading is a method of analyzing and
making trading decisions based solely on the
movements of an asset's price, rather than relying
heavily on technical indicators. Traders use charts,
often candlestick charts, to identify patterns, support
and resistance levels, and trends that can help
predict future price movements.
You’ll learn: how to read a single candle, how short
sequences of candles reveal turning points, and how
larger chart structures (triangles, head & shoulders,
flags) form from repeated behavior. Most importantly,
you’ll learn a simple trading discipline: define entry,
stop-loss, and position size before you trade, and let
the market validate your plan. Practice steadily, keep
a journal, and expect steady improvement — price
action rewards patience and clear rules.

name: Understanding Candlesticks
description:
Candlesticks visually represent an asset's price
movement over a specific time frame, showing four
key prices: open, high, low, and close. The colored
"body" of the candlestick shows the range between
the open and close, with a green or white body
indicating a price increase (bullish) and a red or
black body showing a price decrease (bearish).
Lines above and below the body, called "wicks" or
"shadows," show the highest and lowest prices
reached during that period.
Open: The starting price for the time period.
High: The highest price reached during the period.
Low: The lowest price reached during the period.
Close: The final price of the period.
Body: The rectangular part that shows the
difference between the open and close.
Wicks/Shadows: The lines above and below the
body that show the highest and lowest prices. 9

name: Importance of Timeframes
description:
A timeframe shows how much time each candle
represents such as 1 minute, 15 minutes, 1 hour, 4
hour, 1 day or 1 week.
Shorter timeframes show quick price moves and
noise, while higher timeframes reveal stronger trends
and clearer market direction.
Professional traders use multiple timeframes
together: higher ones for trend confirmation and
lower ones for precise entries.
Choosing the right timeframe helps you match your
strategy, control emotions, and avoid false signals
caused by short-term market noise.
key_rules: Lower timeframes (1m–15m): Good for scalping,
but more noise.
Medium (1H–4H): Ideal for intraday traders.
Higher (Daily–Weekly): Best for swing and
position trading.
Top-down analysis: Start with higher timeframe
to find trend, then drop to lower to time entries.
Patterns repeat on all timeframes reliability
increases with higher ones.

name: Psychology Behind Candlestick Movements
description:
4.Psychology Behind Candlestick
Movements
Every candlestick reflects the emotions and decisions
of market participants by showing fear, greed,
confidence, or hesitation.
When buyers dominate, prices close higher; when
sellers control, prices close lower.
Long candles show strong conviction, while dojis and
spinning tops signal indecision.
By studying candle formations, traders can read the
crowd’s psychology who is in control, who is trapped,
and when momentum is weakening or shifting toward
a possible reversal.
Candlestick Psychology

name: Reading Market Sentiment through Candles
description:
5.Reading Market Sentiment
through Candles
Market sentiment shows how traders collectively feel
about price bullish (positive), bearish (negative), or
neutral (indecisive).
Candlestick patterns help visualize this sentiment in
real time.
A series of strong bullish candles indicates growing
confidence, while repeated bearish candles show fear
or pressure.
Doji or small-bodied candles reveal hesitation.
By studying these sequences along with trend and
volume, traders can judge if the market’s mood
supports continuation or warns of an upcoming
reversal.

name: Support & Resistance
description:
What is Support in Trading?
Support in trading defines the price point where
investors show buying interest to stop price declines.
You can use this technical concept to locate price
points which attract enough buying interest to stop
downward price movements.
The asset price tends to recover through upward
movement when it reaches this point because investors
recognize good value at this level.
Support is the opposite of resistance. Support functions
as a price floor below the market value while resistance
functions as a price ceiling above the market value
because sellers use it to push prices down.
Identifying Support levels
The identification of support levels occurs through
the analysis of historical price charts which show
instances where prices stopped declining. The
identification of these key trading levels enables
traders to determine their entry points while deciding
whether to purchase or establish stop-loss orders.
Key Points About Support:
A strong support level indicates that a downtrend
might transition into an uptrend.
Support levels exhibit a non-static characteristic
because they transform according to market
conditions.
Support levels tend to match important
psychological price points because investors tend
to make decisions at these points.
The strength of support increases with each
unsuccessful attempt of the price to penetrate
below the level.
What is Resistance in Trading?
Resistance in trading defines the price levels in
trading that sellers actively defend to stop price
increases. The technical concept enables traders to
locate price points where selling interest becomes
strong enough to drive prices downward.
The asset price encounters downward pressure at
this level because sellers consider it an optimal point
to sell which may cause a price reversal.
Resistance is the opposite of support. Support is a
price floor below the market value, while resistance is
a price ceiling above the market value, where selling
pressure tends to push prices down.
Identifying Resistance levels
The identification of resistance levels requires
studying historical price charts to determine the points
where prices failed to ascend. Traders use this
knowledge to determine their sell order positions and
stop-loss points.
Key Points About Resistance:
A strong resistance level means that an uptrend
may reverse into a downtrend.
Resistance levels are not fixed and can change
based on the market conditions.
Resistance often occurs at significant
psychological price points where traders make
key decisions.
The more times the price fails to break through a
resistance level, the stronger that resistance is
considered.

name: Hammer
description:
A Hammer candlestick forms after a downtrend and
signals a potential bullish reversal.
It has a small body near the top, a long lower wick (at
least twice the body length), and little or no upper
wick.
This shape shows that sellers pushed prices down
sharply, but buyers fought back and closed near the
high.
This price rejection at lower levels indicates that
selling pressure is weakening and buying interest is
returning a sign the trend may reverse upward.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend — potential reversal
signal.
Lower wick ≥ 2x the body; upper wick very small
or absent.
Body color (green or red) doesn’t change meaning
but a green body shows stronger reversal.
Most reliable near support zones, trendlines, or
psychological levels.
Confirmation comes from the next bullish candle
closing above the hammer’s high.
Volume increase strengthens validity of the
pattern.
trend:
Existing Trend: Downtrend or declining market.
Post-pattern Trend: Possible shift to an uptrend if
confirmed by follow-up bullish candle and volume
rise.
Best Zones: Appears at support levels, demand
zones, or after oversold RSI conditions.
The hammer implies that buyers are stepping in
and sellers are exhausted.
It warns that the downtrend may end soon and
a trend reversal or short-term pullback could
follow.
Traders often use it as a buy signal when the
next candle closes above the hammer’s high
with healthy volume.

name: Inverted Hammer
description:
An Inverted Hammer forms after a downtrend and
signals a possible bullish reversal.
It has a small body near the bottom, a long upper
wick (at least twice the body), and little or no lower
wick.
This shape shows buyers tried to push prices higher
but faced resistance.
However, the strong upward rejection indicates that
buying pressure is returning.
If the next candle closes above the Inverted
Hammer’s high, it confirms a potential trend change
from bearish to bullish.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend — hints at a reversal or
pause.
Upper wick ≥ 2x body size; small or no lower wick.
Body color (green or red) is less important —
green adds strength.
Works best at support zones or after sharp
declines.
Requires confirmation candle closing above the
Inverted Hammer’s high.
Volume surge improves reliability.
trend:
Existing Trend: Downtrend or bearish momentum.
Post-pattern Trend: Possible upward reversal
once confirmed.
Best Location: Near major support levels, demand
zones, or after a strong down move.
Often appears before a bullish breakout in short-
term charts.

name: Spinning Top
description:
A Spinning Top candlestick has a small body with
long upper and lower wicks, showing that buyers and
sellers were active but neither gained full control.
It usually appears after a strong uptrend or
downtrend, signaling indecision or a possible pause
in market direction.
When seen near key support or resistance levels, it
warns that momentum is weakening and the market
could reverse or consolidate before choosing its next
move.
key_rules: Has a small body and long wicks on both sides.
Indicates indecision between buyers and sellers.
Works best after sharp moves or at key levels.
Color (green or red) doesn’t affect meaning much.
Often followed by a breakout or reversal candle.
Confirmation from the next candle’s direction is
essential.
trend:
The Spinning Top implies market uncertainty neither
buyers nor sellers are confident enough to take full
control.
If followed by a strong bullish candle, it signals a
possible reversal upward; if followed by a bearish
candle, it suggests continuation downward.
Traders often wait for confirmation before entering,
using the next candle’s close as a directional clue

name: Shooting Star
description:
A Shooting Star candlestick forms after an uptrend
and signals a potential bearish reversal.
It has a small body near the bottom, a long upper
wick (at least twice the body length), and little or no
lower wick.
This pattern shows buyers pushed prices up strongly,
but sellers stepped in and forced the price back near
the open.
It indicates that buying pressure is weakening and
selling pressure is emerging, often marking the start
of a downward correction.
Shooting Star
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend — warns of bearish
reversal.
Best seen at resistance levels or near previous
swing highs.
Confirmation candle must close below the
Shooting Star’s low.
High volume strengthens reliability of the reversal.28
trend:
The Shooting Star implies that upward momentum is
fading and that a trend reversal may be near.
If the next candle is strongly bearish and closes
below the Shooting Star’s low, it confirms the start of
a downward move.

name: Gravestone Doji
description:
A Gravestone Doji forms when the open, low, and
close are nearly equal, but the high is far above the
body, creating a long upper wick.
It shows that buyers pushed prices up strongly during
the session, but sellers forced them back down to the
open by the close.
This sharp rejection of higher prices often appears at
the top of an uptrend, warning of a potential bearish
reversal or exhaustion of buying strength
key_rules: Looks like an inverted “T” shape — long upper
wick, flat base.
Appears mostly after an uptrend — bearish
warning.
Indicates strong rejection of higher prices.
Best signal when followed by a bearish
confirmation candle.
Stronger when it forms at resistance levels or
overbought zones.
trend:
The Gravestone Doji implies that buyers are
exhausted, and sellers are returning.
It signals a shift from bullish to bearish sentiment,
especially when confirmed by volume and a strong
red candle afterward.
Traders often enter short positions below the
Gravestone Doji’s low once confirmation appears.

name: Dragonfly Doji
description:
A Dragonfly Doji has the open, high, and close
nearly equal, with a long lower wick and little or no
upper wick.
It appears after a downtrend and signals bullish
reversal potential.
During its formation, sellers drove prices lower, but
buyers regained full control and closed the candle
near its open or high.
This strong rejection from lower prices shows
renewed buying interest, hinting that the downtrend
may be ending.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend — bullish reversal
sign.
Shows buyers absorbing selling pressure.
Stronger when seen at support zones or oversold
conditions.
Works best when accompanied by increased
volume.
trend:
The Dragonfly Doji implies that buyers are gaining
control after a decline.
It’s often the first sign that the downtrend may end
soon.
A bullish confirmation candle closing above the
Dragonfly’s high can trigger a buy entry, with stop-loss
below the candle’s low.

name: Hanging Man
description:
A Hanging Man candlestick appears after an uptrend
and warns of a possible bearish reversal.
It has a small body near the top, a long lower wick (at
least twice the body size), and little or no upper wick.
Although buyers pushed prices up, strong selling
during the session shows that sellers are beginning to
resist higher prices.
This candle signals that the uptrend may be
weakening, and traders should watch for a potential
decline if confirmed by the next candle.
key_rules: Appears after a strong uptrend — bearish reversal
warning.
Works best near resistance zones or round-
number price levels.
Needs confirmation from the next candle closing
below the low of the Hanging Man.
High trading volume strengthens the reliability
trend:
The Hanging Man implies that the bullish momentum is
weakening, and sellers are entering the market.
It serves as an early warning of a potential price drop
or correction.
Traders often prepare for short entries once the next
candle closes below the Hanging Man’s low, setting
stop-loss above its high.

name: Bullish Marubozu
description:
A Bullish Marubozu is a single strong bullish candle
that shows complete control by buyers.
It opens at the session’s low and closes at the
session’s high, with no upper or lower wicks.
This means buyers were dominant from start to finish,
pushing prices continuously upward.
It often appears at the beginning of a new uptrend,
during a breakout, or as a confirmation of bullish
momentum signaling strong confidence and clear
direction in the market.
key_rules: Indicates strong buying momentum and market
confidence.
No wicks — open = low, close = high.
Appears in uptrends or breakouts.
Confirms trend continuation or reversal strength.
Stronger when supported by high trading volume.
Works well near support zones or breakout levels.
trend:
A Bullish Marubozu implies that buyers are fully in
control, and prices may continue rising.
It’s considered a strong bullish confirmation candle.
Traders often enter long after the candle’s close with
stop-loss below its low.
When followed by additional bullish candles, it often
marks the start of a sustained rally.

name: Bearish Marubozu
description:
A Bearish Marubozu is a single strong bearish candle
that shows complete control by sellers.
It opens at the session’s high and closes at the
session’s low, with no upper or lower wicks.
This indicates that sellers were in charge throughout
the session, pushing prices consistently downward.
It often forms at the start of a downtrend, during
breakouts below support, or as confirmation of selling
pressure, suggesting strong bearish sentiment and
market conviction.
key_rules: Indicates strong selling pressure and market
dominance by bears.
No wicks — open = high, close = low.
Appears during downtrends.
Confirms bearish continuation.
High volume adds reliability.
trend:
A Bearish Marubozu implies complete dominance of
sellers and a clear bearish bias in the market.
It signals a high probability of further decline,
especially when confirmed by volume or following
bearish patterns.
Traders often enter short below the candle’s close
with stop-loss above its high.
It’s a strong sign of panic or aggressive selling.

name: Pin Bar
description:
A Pin Bar (short for “Pinocchio Bar”) is a single-
candle reversal pattern that signals rejection of a
particular price level.
It has a small body and a long tail (wick) on one side
either upper or lower which shows where price was
rejected.
A long lower wick (Bullish Pin Bar) indicates rejection
of lower prices and potential upward reversal, while a
long upper wick (Bearish Pin Bar) suggests rejection
of higher prices and a possible downward move.
key_rules: Appears at key support or resistance levels.
Has a small body and a long wick.
Bullish Pin Bar: long lower wick → rejection of
lows.
Bearish Pin Bar: long upper wick → rejection of
highs.
Works best with trend context and
support/resistance confluence.
Confirmation required from next candle closing in
reversal direction.
Often used in price action trading and smart
money concepts.
trend:
Bullish Pin Bar: Appears after a downtrend
potential reversal upward.
Bearish Pin Bar: Appears after an uptrend
potential reversal downward.
Best Zones: Near support/resistance, trendline
bounces, or supply/demand zones.
The Pin Bar implies strong rejection and a possible
shift in momentum.
A bullish Pin Bar signals that buyers are defending
support zones, while a bearish Pin Bar signals that
sellers are defending resistance.
Traders often enter trades in the direction opposite to
the wick, setting stop-loss beyond the wick’s end.
It’s a key pattern for reversal entries and trend
continuation pullbacks.

name: Bullish Engulfing
description:
A Bullish Engulfing pattern forms after a downtrend
and signals a strong bullish reversal.
It consists of two candles — the first one is bearish
(red), and the second one is bullish (green) that
completely engulfs the body of the first candle.
This shows that buyers have overpowered sellers,
shifting control of the market.
The large bullish candle represents strong
momentum, indicating that the downtrend may be
ending and a new upward move could begin.
Bullish Engulfing
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend — reversal to bullish.
Formed by two candles: 1st bearish, 2nd bullish.
The bullish candle’s body fully covers the
previous bearish candle.
Stronger when accompanied by high volume.
Best near support zones or oversold levels.
Confirmation occurs when the next candle closes
above the bullish candle’s high.
trend:
The Bullish Engulfing implies a shift of power from
sellers to buyers.
It’s one of the most dependable signs of a trend
reversal when confirmed by volume and follow-
through.
Traders typically enter long above the engulfing
candle’s high, with a stop-loss below its low.

name: Bearish Engulfing
description:
A Bearish Engulfing pattern forms after an uptrend
and signals a possible bearish reversal.
It consists of two candles the first is bullish (green)
and the second is bearish (red) with a body that
completely engulfs the previous candle’s body.
This shows that sellers have overtaken buyers,
reversing momentum.
The strong bearish candle indicates that the uptrend
is weakening, and prices may start to decline as
selling pressure increases.
Bearish Engulfing
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend bearish reversal sign.
Consists of two candles: first bullish, second bearish
(larger body).
The bearish candle fully covers the prior candle’s
body.
Volume spike strengthens the reliability of reversal.
Works best at resistance zones.
Confirmation when next candle closes below the
engulfing candle’s low. 45
trend:
The Bearish Engulfing implies a clear power shift
from buyers to sellers.
It’s a strong warning that upside momentum is fading.
When confirmed by volume or momentum indicators,
it can signal the start of a downward trend or deeper
correction.

name: Bullish Harami
description:
A Bullish Harami pattern appears after a downtrend
and signals a potential bullish reversal.
It consists of two candles — the first is a large
bearish (red) candle, followed by a small bullish
(green) candle that forms entirely within the body of
the first candle.
This shows that selling pressure is slowing down, and
buyers are cautiously returning.
The shrinking body size reflects indecision and trend
exhaustion, hinting that the downtrend may soon
reverse if buyers confirm strength in the next session.
Bullish Harami
key_rules: Indicates loss of bearish momentum.
Works best at support zones or after sharp
declines.
Volume rise on the second candle adds reliability.
Confirmation when next candle closes above the
Harami’s high.
trend:
The Bullish Harami implies that sellers are losing
dominance and buyers are regaining confidence.
It’s a conservative signal suggesting trend exhaustion
rather than a sudden reversal.
Traders often enter long after a bullish confirmation
candle, setting stop-loss below the Harami’s low.
It’s especially valuable when accompanied by volume
increase or bullish divergence on indicators.

name: Bearish Harami
description:
A Bearish Harami pattern forms after an uptrend and
signals a possible bearish reversal.
It consists of two candles — the first is a large bullish
(green) candle, followed by a small bearish (red)
candle that forms entirely within the body of the first.
This pattern shows that buying momentum is fading
and sellers are slowly taking over.
The narrow range of the second candle reflects
indecision and loss of strength, hinting that the
uptrend may be nearing its end.
Bearish Harami
key_rules: Indicates buying weakness and market
hesitation.
Stronger when found near resistance zones or
previous highs.
Volume drop on the second candle strengthens
validity.
Confirmation when next candle closes below the
Harami’s low.
trend:
The Bearish Harami implies that bullish momentum is
fading, and sellers are gaining confidence.
It’s not an immediate sell signal but a warning of
potential reversal.
Traders often enter short after a bearish confirmation
candle closes below the Harami’s low, setting stop-
loss above its high.
It reflects market hesitation and possible shift from
optimism to caution.

name: Morning Star Pattern
description:
21.Morning Star
The Morning Star is a three-candle bullish reversal
pattern that forms after a downtrend.
It begins with a large bearish candle, followed by a
small indecisive candle (Doji or Spinning Top), and
ends with a strong bullish candle that closes well into
the first candle’s body.
It signals that the downtrend may be ending, and a
new upward move is likely to begin.
Morning Star
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend signals a bullish reversal.
Consists of three candles:
1⃣ Long bearish candle (sellers in control)
2⃣ Small body or Doji (indecision)
3⃣ Strong bullish candle (buyers take over)
The third candle should close above the midpoint of
the first candle.
Volume increase on the third candle adds strength.
Works best at support zones or after long
downtrends.
trend:
The Morning Star implies that sellers are exhausted
and buyers are returning.
It’s a clear indication of trend reversal strength,
especially when accompanied by volume
confirmation.
Traders often enter long above the third candle’s
high, placing a stop-loss below the pattern’s low.

name: Evening Star Pattern
description:
22.Evening Star
The Evening Star is a three-candle bearish reversal
pattern that forms after an uptrend.
It starts with a large bullish candle, followed by a
small indecisive candle (Doji or Spinning Top), and
ends with a strong bearish candle that closes deep
into the first candle’s body.
The pattern signals that the uptrend may be ending,
and a downward reversal could be underway.
Evening Star
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend signals bearish reversal.
Consists of three candles:
Large bullish candle (strong buying)
Small candle or Doji (indecision)
Large bearish candle (strong selling)
The third candle should close below the midpoint of
the first candle.
Volume confirmation on the bearish candle
strengthens reliability. 53
trend:
The Evening Star implies that buyers are exhausted,
and sellers are taking control.
It acts as an early warning for a potential downtrend
or major price correction.
Traders often enter short below the third candle’s low
with a stop-loss above the pattern’s high.

name: Three White Soldiers
description:
The Three White Soldiers pattern is a three-candle
bullish reversal formation that appears after a
downtrend.
It consists of three consecutive long bullish (green)
candles, each opening within or near the previous
candle’s body and closing progressively higher.
This steady upward movement shows strong and
consistent buying pressure.
It indicates that buyers have taken full control of the
market and a new uptrend may be starting, especially
when supported by volume and market confirmation.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend signals strong bullish
reversal.
Three long bullish candles closing higher each day.
Each candle opens within or near the previous
candle’s body.
No large upper wicks, showing sustained buying
interest.
Works best with increasing volume.
trend:
The Three White Soldiers implies strong bullish
momentum and renewed confidence in the market.
It’s one of the most reliable reversal signals, especially
when supported by rising volume and confirmation from
indicators.
Traders typically enter long after the third candle
closes, setting a stop-loss below the first candle’s low.
It often marks the beginning of a sustainable uptrend.

name: Three Black Crows
description:
The Three Black Crows pattern is a three-candle
bearish reversal formation that appears after an
uptrend.
It consists of three consecutive long bearish (red)
candles, each opening within or near the previous
candle’s body and closing progressively lower.
This steady downward move shows consistent selling
pressure and signals that buyers are losing control.
The formation warns of a potential trend reversal and
is strongest when accompanied by high trading
volume and confirmation from technical indicators.
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend signals a bearish reversal.
Three long bearish candles closing lower each
session.
Each candle opens within or near the previous
candle’s body.
No lower wicks sellers dominated throughout.
Works best with rising volume and confirmation from
indicators.
trend:
The Three Black Crows implies intense selling pressure
and loss of bullish confidence.
It often marks the start of a downward trend or
correction phase.
Traders usually enter short below the third candle’s low,
setting stop-loss above the first candle’s high.
It’s a visual warning of bearish dominance, signaling
traders to exit long positions or prepare for downside
moves.

name: Tweezer Top
description:
25. Tweezer Top
A Tweezer Top forms after an uptrend and signals a
possible bearish reversal.
It consists of two candles with almost equal highs,
often showing strong rejection at a resistance level.
The first candle is bullish, continuing the trend, and
the second is bearish, opening near the previous
high but closing lower.
This pattern shows that buyers tried to push prices
higher again but failed, revealing seller strength and
a possible end of the uptrend.
Top(Bearish)
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend — bearish reversal signal.
Formed by two candles with identical or nearly equal
highs.
First candle: bullish; second: bearish.
Shows rejection of resistance or double-top behavior.
Works best with volume spike on the second candle.
Confirmation when the price closes below both
candles’ lows.
trend:
The Tweezer Top implies that the market rejected
higher prices twice in a row.
It shows bullish exhaustion and the start of selling
momentum.
Traders often enter short below the pattern’s low with a
stop-loss above the highs.
It’s most reliable when confirmed by a strong bearish
candle or high trading volume.

name: Tweezer Bottom
description:
A Tweezer Bottom forms after a downtrend and
signals a potential bullish reversal.
It consists of two candles with nearly equal lows,
showing rejection of lower prices.
The first candle is bearish, and the second is bullish,
opening near the previous low but closing higher.
This shows that sellers tried to continue the
downtrend but failed, and buyers stepped in strongly,
marking the possible start of a new upward
movement.
Bottom(Bullish)
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend bullish reversal pattern.
Formed by two candles with identical or nearly equal
lows.
First candle: bearish; second: bullish.
Indicates rejection of support or double-bottom
behavior.
Works best when the second candle closes above the
first’s high.
trend:
The Tweezer Bottom implies that the market rejected
lower prices twice, confirming buyer strength.
It signals that sellers are weakening, and buyers may
soon take control.
Traders often enter long above the second candle’s
high with a stop-loss below the lows.
It’s a simple yet powerful confirmation of bottom
reversal.

name: Double Top
description:
27. Double Top
The Double Top is a bearish reversal chart pattern
that forms after a strong uptrend.
It consists of two consecutive peaks (tops) at nearly
the same price level, separated by a moderate trough
(neckline).
This pattern shows that the market has tested a
resistance level twice but failed both times to break
above it.
When the price finally breaks below the neckline, it
confirms a trend reversal signaling that sellers have
taken control and a downtrend may begin.
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend — signals bearish reversal.
Formed by two peaks at similar levels and a neckline
between them.
Second top shows buyer exhaustion and resistance
confirmation.
Pattern completes when price breaks below neckline.
Volume typically decreases on the second top,
confirming weakness.
trend:
The Double Top implies that buyers are losing strength,
and sellers are regaining control.
It’s a warning of potential trend reversal, often marking
the transition from bullish to bearish sentiment.
Traders typically enter short after a confirmed break
below the neckline, with a stop-loss above the second
top.
The pattern is reliable when supported by volume
increase during breakdown.

name: Double Bottom
description:
28. Double Bottom
The Double Bottom is a bullish reversal chart pattern
that forms after a strong downtrend.
It consists of two consecutive lows (bottoms) at
nearly the same price level, separated by a moderate
peak (neckline).
This pattern shows that the market tested a support
level twice and failed to break below it.
When the price breaks above the neckline, it confirms
that buyers have regained control, signaling a
potential uptrend or strong bullish recovery.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend signals bullish reversal.
Formed by two lows at a similar level and a neckline
between them.
Second bottom confirms support zone strength.
Pattern completes when price breaks above neckline.
Volume often increases on the breakout, confirming
buying interest.
trend:
The Double Bottom implies that sellers failed to push
prices lower twice, confirming a strong support level.
It’s one of the most reliable signs that the downtrend is
ending and buyers are returning.
Traders typically enter long after a confirmed break
above the neckline, placing a stop-loss below the
second bottom.

name: Triple Top
description:
29. Triple Top
The Triple Top is a bearish reversal chart pattern that
appears after a prolonged uptrend.
It consists of three peaks at roughly the same price
level, separated by two troughs, forming a clear
horizontal resistance.
Each attempt to break above this resistance fails,
showing that buyers are losing momentum.
Once the price breaks below the neckline (the
support line connecting the two troughs), it confirms
the pattern and signals a potential downtrend or
bearish reversal.
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend — indicates bearish
reversal.
Composed of three equal highs (tops) and two lows
(neckline).
Resistance zone is tested three times but not broken.
Pattern confirms when price breaks below neckline.
Volume decreases with each peak, signaling
weakening buyers. 67
trend:
The Triple Top implies complete buyer exhaustion and
a clear transition to selling pressure.
It’s a powerful indicator that the uptrend has ended and
a new bearish phase is starting.
Traders often enter short after a confirmed break below
the neckline, placing stop-loss above the third top.
The pattern becomes more reliable when accompanied
by rising volume during the breakdown.

name: Triple Bottom
description:
The Triple Bottom is a bullish reversal chart pattern
that forms after a downtrend.
It consists of three consecutive lows at approximately
the same price level, separated by two peaks
(neckline).
Each time the market tests this support level, buyers
step in and prevent further decline.
This repeated defense of support shows that selling
pressure is weakening.
When price breaks above the neckline, it confirms a
bullish reversal, signaling that buyers are regaining
control and an uptrend may begin.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend indicates bullish reversal.
Formed by three equal lows (bottoms) and two highs
(neckline).
Support zone tested three times and holds strong.
Pattern confirms when price breaks above neckline.
Volume increases on breakout, confirming buying
momentum.
trend:
The Triple Bottom implies strong support and
accumulation by buyers.
It’s a visual confirmation that sellers have failed multiple
times, and buyers are preparing for a breakout.
Traders typically enter long after a confirmed close
above the neckline, placing stop-loss below the third
bottom.
The pattern is most powerful when confirmed by
increasing volume or bullish indicators.

name: Head & Shoulders
description:
31.Head and shoulders
The Head and Shoulders is a bearish reversal chart
pattern that forms after an uptrend.
It consists of three peaks a left shoulder, a higher
middle peak (the head), and a right shoulder of
similar height to the first.
A neckline connects the two troughs between the
shoulders.
When the price breaks below the neckline, it confirms
the pattern, signaling that buyers are losing strength
and sellers are taking control, often leading to a trend
reversal.
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend signals bearish reversal.
Composed of three peaks: Left Shoulder, Head, Right
Shoulder.
Head is the highest point; shoulders are of similar
height.
Neckline connects the two swing lows.
Pattern confirms when price breaks below neckline. 71
trend:
The Head and Shoulders implies that the uptrend is
over and a bearish phase may begin.
It’s one of the most reliable reversal formations,
especially with volume confirmation during the
breakdown.
Traders usually enter short after a confirmed break
below the neckline, setting stop-loss above the right
shoulder.
The pattern signals a shift in market sentiment — from
optimism to selling pressure.

name: Inverted Head & Shoulders
description:
32.Inverse Head and shoulders
The Inverse Head and Shoulders is a bullish reversal
pattern that forms after a downtrend.
It features three consecutive troughs (lows) — a left
shoulder, a lower middle trough (the head), and a
right shoulder similar in depth to the left.
A neckline connects the peaks between these
troughs.
When the price breaks above the neckline, it confirms
a trend reversal, signaling that buyers are regaining
strength and a new uptrend may begin.
key_rules: Appears after a downtrend signals bullish reversal.
Composed of three lows: Left Shoulder, Head
(lowest), Right Shoulder.
Neckline connects the two swing highs.
Pattern confirms when price breaks above neckline.
Volume usually increases on the breakout, confirming
buyer strength. 73
trend:
The Inverse Head and Shoulders implies seller
exhaustion and buyer accumulation.
It’s a strong signal that the downtrend has likely ended,
and bullish sentiment is returning.
Traders often enter long after a confirmed break above
the neckline, with stop-loss below the right shoulder.
A volume surge during breakout strengthens
confirmation, marking the start of a potential uptrend.

name: Rising wedges
description:
The Rising Wedge is a bearish chart pattern that can
form either after an uptrend (reversal) or during a
downtrend (continuation).
It consists of two upward-sloping trendlines that
converge as price moves higher the upper line acts
as resistance and the lower line as support.
While prices continue to rise, the slope narrows,
signaling weakening momentum.
A breakdown below the lower trendline confirms the
pattern and suggests a potential bearish move
ahead.
Rising Wedge
key_rules: Shape: Two rising, converging trendlines (narrowing
price channel).
Trend Type: Bearish signals reversal or continuation.
Volume decreases during formation, showing
weakening buyers.
Breakdown below support confirms bearish bias.
trend:
The Rising Wedge implies weakening bullish pressure
and a potential bearish shift.
It often precedes sharp downside movements as
trapped buyers exit positions.
Traders usually enter short after the price breaks below
the lower trendline, with a stop-loss above the last
swing high.
It’s one of the most reliable early warning patterns for
trend reversals.

name: Falling Wedges
description:
34.Falling Wedge
The Falling Wedge is a bullish chart pattern that
forms after a downtrend (reversal) or during an
uptrend (continuation).
It consists of two downward-sloping trendlines that
converge, showing narrowing price movement.
As the range tightens, sellers lose strength while
buyers begin accumulating.
When price breaks above the upper trendline, it
confirms a bullish breakout signaling that buyers
have regained control and a potential upward move
or trend reversal is underway.
key_rules: Shape: Two converging downward-sloping trendlines.
Indicates decreasing selling pressure and
accumulation.
Can act as a reversal in a downtrend or continuation
in an uptrend.
Volume declines during wedge formation and rises on
breakout.
trend:
The Falling Wedge implies seller exhaustion and a
likely bullish shift in market control.
It’s a strong technical signal that the downtrend may be
ending.
Traders typically enter long after a confirmed breakout
above the upper trendline, placing stop-loss below the
last swing low.
It’s one of the most powerful reversal setups when
combined with volume and divergence confirmation.

name: Ascending Triangles
description:
35.Ascending Triangle
The Ascending Triangle is a bullish continuation
pattern that forms during an uptrend.
It’s made up of a horizontal resistance line at the top
and a rising trendline below.
This means buyers are entering at higher prices each
time, while sellers repeatedly defend the same
resistance.
As price compresses, momentum builds for a
breakout.
When price closes above the resistance line, it
confirms the pattern and often leads to a strong
bullish continuation or new uptrend.
Ascending Triangle
key_rules: Shape: Flat resistance (top) + rising support (bottom).
Appears during an uptrend signals bullish
continuation.
Shows higher lows as buyers gain strength.
Pattern completes with a breakout above resistance.
Volume contracts during formation and expands on
breakout. 79
trend:
The Ascending Triangle implies buyer strength and
breakout potential.
It often precedes strong bullish momentum as trapped
sellers exit positions.
Traders typically enter long after a confirmed breakout
above resistance, with stop-loss below the last higher
low.
The pattern’s reliability increases when accompanied
by rising volume and strong trend confirmation.

name: Descending Triangles
description:
36.Descending Triangle
The Descending Triangle is a bearish continuation
pattern that forms during a downtrend.
It consists of a horizontal support line at the bottom
and a descending resistance line above.
This shows that sellers are getting stronger, pushing
prices lower each time, while buyers try to hold a
fixed support level.
As the range tightens, pressure builds until price
breaks below the support line, confirming the pattern
and signaling a potential continuation of the
downtrend.
Descending Triangle
key_rules: Shape: Flat support (bottom) + descending resistance
(top).
Appears during a downtrend — signals bearish
continuation.
Shows lower highs, meaning sellers dominate.
Pattern confirms on breakdown below support.
Volume decreases during formation, increases on
breakout.
trend:
The Descending Triangle implies persistent selling
pressure and buyer weakness.
It’s a warning that support may soon fail, leading to
further downside.
Traders usually enter short after a confirmed close
below the support line, with a stop-loss above the last
lower high.
The pattern is often followed by sharp breakdowns due
to stop-loss triggers and panic selling.

name: Symmetrical Triangle
description:
The Symmetrical Triangle is a neutral continuation
pattern that can signal a breakout or breakdown,
depending on which side wins control.
It consists of two converging trendlines one
descending (upper) and one ascending (lower)
showing lower highs and higher lows.
This pattern reflects a period of indecision and
consolidation where price volatility contracts.
When the price finally breaks out of the triangle, it
confirms the new direction upward in uptrends or
downward in downtrends.
key_rules: Shape: Two converging diagonal trendlines (one
descending, one ascending).
Represents indecision and consolidation before a
breakout.
Neutral pattern breakout can occur in either direction.
Volume contracts during formation and expands
sharply on breakout.
trend:
The Symmetrical Triangle implies market balance and
pressure build-up.
It’s a sign that a major move is coming, though the
direction depends on the breakout.
Traders typically wait for a candle close beyond either
trendline to confirm direction.
Long entries are made on upward breakouts; short
entries on downward ones, with stop-loss inside the
triangle.

name: Dark Cloud Cover
description:
The Dark Cloud Cover is a two-candle bearish
reversal pattern that forms after an uptrend.
The first candle is bullish (green), showing strong
buying momentum, while the second candle is
bearish (red) that opens above the previous high but
closes below the midpoint of the first candle.
This sudden shift shows selling pressure entering the
market.
It signals that the uptrend may be losing strength,
and a downward reversal could be near if confirmed
by a bearish continuation candle.
Dark Cloud Cover
key_rules: Appears after an uptrend bearish reversal indicator.
Two candles:
Long bullish candle (buyers in control).
Bearish candle opening above the previous high but
closing below midpoint.
Gap-up opening enhances signal strength.
Works best near resistance or overbought regions.
trend:
The Dark Cloud Cover implies that buying momentum
is fading and sellers are stepping in.
It’s a strong early warning that a top may be forming.
Traders often enter short below the bearish candle’s
low with a stop-loss above its high.
When confirmed by increasing volume or RSI
divergence, it signals a potential trend reversal.

name: Cup and Handle
description:
The Cup and Handle is a bullish continuation pattern
that forms after a strong upward move.
It resembles the shape of a tea cup the cup
represents a rounded bottom formed by a gradual
decline and recovery, while the handle represents a
short pullback or consolidation.
This pattern shows a period of accumulation before a
breakout.
When price breaks above the handle’s resistance, it
confirms trend continuation, signaling a strong bullish
momentum ahead.
Cup And Handle
key_rules: Appears during an uptrend signals bullish
continuation.
Cup: Rounded bottom showing gradual accumulation.
Handle: Small pullback after recovery.
Pattern confirms when price breaks above handle
resistance.
Volume decreases during cup formation and
increases on breakout.
trend:
The Cup and Handle implies strong buyer
accumulation and renewed bullish momentum.
It’s a sign that the market has digested earlier gains
and is ready for the next breakout.
Traders often enter long after a confirmed breakout
above the handle, with stoploss below the handle’s low.
The larger and more symmetrical the cup, the more
reliable the pattern.

name: Bullish Flag
description:
The Bullish Flag is a continuation pattern that forms
after a sharp upward price move.
It resembles a flag on a pole the flagpole represents
a strong rally, and the flag represents a short-term
consolidation or downward-sloping channel.
This pattern shows that after a quick rise, traders are
taking profits, but buyers are still in control.
When price breaks above the flag’s upper trendline, it
confirms trend continuation and signals the next
bullish leg upward.
Bullish Flag
key_rules: Structure: Sharp rally (flagpole) + downward-sloping
flag.
Appears during an uptrend signals bullish
continuation.
Shows temporary consolidation after a strong move.
Pattern confirms when price breaks above flag
resistance.
Volume declines during flag formation and increases
on breakout.
trend:
It shows that buyers are simply pausing before pushing
prices higher.
Traders typically enter long on a confirmed breakout
above the flag, placing stoploss below the flag’s lower
line.
It’s one of the most profitable patterns for momentum
traders, especially when confirmed by volume spike on
breakout.

name: Bearish Flag
description:
The Bearish Flag is a continuation pattern that forms
after a sharp downward price move.
It looks like a flag on a pole the flagpole represents a
strong bearish drop, and the flag is a short-term
upward or sideways consolidation.
This pattern shows that sellers are temporarily
pausing, while buyers attempt a weak recovery.
When price breaks below the flag’s lower trendline, it
confirms trend continuation, signaling the start of
another wave of selling pressure.
Bearish Flag
key_rules: Structure: Sharp decline (flagpole) + upward-sloping
or sideways flag.
Appears during a downtrend signals bearish
continuation.
Shows temporary pullback or consolidation before
breakdown.
Pattern confirms when price closes below flag
support.
trend:
The Bearish Flag implies strong selling momentum and
a likely continuation of the existing downtrend.
It shows that the market is simply pausing before
another fall.
Traders often enter short after a confirmed break below
the flag, setting stop-loss above the flag’s upper
boundary.
This pattern helps capture trend continuation moves
with low risk and high reward. 92

name: Rounding Bottom
description:
The Rounding Bottom is a bullish reversal pattern
that forms after a prolonged downtrend.
It has a smooth, U-shaped curve, showing a gradual
shift from selling to buying pressure.
Initially, prices decline slowly, then stabilize, and
finally start rising gradually forming a saucer-like
bottom.
This pattern signals accumulation by long-term
buyers and often marks the end of a downtrend.
When price breaks above the neckline (resistance), it
confirms a new uptrend and bullish momentum.
key_rules: Shape: Smooth U-shaped bottom (saucer form).
Appears after a downtrend — signals bullish reversal.
Represents gradual accumulation and buyer
confidence.
Pattern completes when price breaks above
neckline/resistance.
Volume decreases near the bottom and rises during
breakout. 93
trend:
The Rounding Bottom implies a slow but steady
transfer of control from sellers to buyers.
It’s a strong long-term bullish signal, often preceding
major trend reversals.
Traders usually enter long after a confirmed breakout
above neckline, with stop-loss near the lowest point of
the curve.
It’s one of the most trustworthy bottoming formations
due to its gradual development and clear volume
structure. 94

name: Rounding Top
description:
The Rounding Top is a bearish reversal pattern that
forms after a strong uptrend.
It has a smooth, inverted U-shape, showing a gradual
shift from bullish to bearish sentiment.
At first, buyers push prices higher, but momentum
weakens as sellers begin to dominate.
The rounded shape shows distribution by smart
money and loss of buying strength.
When the price breaks below the neckline (support),
it confirms the bearish reversal and often leads to a
downtrend.
key_rules: Shape: Smooth inverted U-shape (saucer top).
Appears after an uptrend — signals bearish reversal.
Represents buyer fatigue and gradual distribution.
Pattern confirms when price breaks below
neckline/support.
Volume increases during decline and decreases
during topping phase.
trend:
The Rounding Top implies buyer exhaustion and a
transition to selling pressure.
It’s a warning that the uptrend is losing strength, and a
reversal may be near.
Traders typically enter short after a confirmed
breakdown below the neckline, setting stop-loss above
the recent swing high.
This pattern is especially effective when confirmed by
falling volume and momentum divergence.

name: Diamond Top
description:
The Diamond Top is a bearish reversal chart pattern
that forms after a strong uptrend.
It begins with a broadening formation (higher highs
and lower lows), followed by a narrowing formation
(lower highs and higher lows), together forming a
diamond shape.
This pattern shows market indecision and volatility
expansion, followed by contraction.
When price breaks below the lower boundary of the
diamond, it confirms a bearish reversal, signaling that
buyers are losing control and sellers are taking over.
key_rules: Shape: Combination of broadening and symmetrical
triangle forming a diamond.
Appears after an uptrend signals bearish reversal.
Reflects high volatility and trend exhaustion.
Pattern confirms when price breaks below support
(lower boundary).
Volume increases in the broadening phase and
decreases during contraction. 97
trend:
Existing Trend: Uptrend.
Post-pattern Trend: Bearish reversal or downtrend
continuation.
Best Zones: Near market tops, major resistance
levels, or post-rally exhaustion phases.
Works well with volume divergence or bearish
momentum indicators.
The Diamond Top implies trend exhaustion and buyer
weakness after a strong uptrend.
It warns traders that a reversal is imminent as the
market transitions from expansion to contraction.
Traders usually enter short after a confirmed break
below the diamond, with stop-loss above the upper
boundary.
The pattern often precedes sharp corrections or major
bearish reversals.

name: Diamond Bottom
description:
The Diamond Bottom is a bullish reversal chart
pattern that forms after a prolonged downtrend.
It begins with a broadening formation (lower lows and
higher highs) followed by a narrowing formation
(higher lows and lower highs), together forming a
diamond shape.
This pattern represents volatility expansion followed
by compression, showing that sellers are losing
strength while buyers start accumulating.
When price breaks above the diamond’s upper
boundary, it confirms a bullish reversal and signals
the start of a new uptrend.
key_rules: Shape: Broadening + contracting trendlines forming a
diamond.
Appears after a downtrend signals bullish reversal.
Reflects buyer accumulation and decreasing volatility.
Pattern confirms when price breaks above resistance
(upper boundary).
Volume increases during breakout, confirming
demand. 100
trend:
Existing Trend: Downtrend.
Post-pattern Trend: Bullish reversal or uptrend
start.
Best Zones: Near major support levels, bottom
formations, or oversold regions.
Works best when volume rises during breakout and
momentum indicators turn bullish.
The Diamond Bottom implies seller exhaustion and
buyer strength building at the end of a downtrend.
It’s a sign that the market has absorbed all selling
pressure and is preparing for a trend reversal.
Traders typically enter long after a confirmed breakout
above the diamond, with stop-loss below the lower
boundary.
This pattern often marks the early phase of long-term
trend reversals.
The Final Thought
Thank you for reading. Candlestick patterns are a
language the more you read charts, the more fluent
you become.
Start small: practise pattern recognition on higher
timeframes, trade with well-defined risk, and journal
every trade. Consistency and discipline matter far
more than finding “perfect” setups.
Final tips
Use higher-timeframe bias first, then trade lower-
timeframe entries.
Wait for confirmation a single candle rarely tells
the whole story.
Keep risk per trade small (1–2%); protect capital.
Review trades weekly; learn from both wins and
losses.
Disclaimer
This book is educational not investment advice.
Trading involves risk. Always do your own research
and consider professional guidance.
Contact / Feedback
Author: Nawaz Ashraf
I’d love your feedback and real-world samples from
your practice journal.
